tn.ref: General Information:
tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: A prayer of David
tn.text: "This is a prayer that David wrote."

tn.ref: Give ear to my prayer from lips without deceit
tn.text: The term "give ear" refers to listening, and the word "lips" refers to the words a person speaks. AT: "Listen to my prayer which does not come from lying lips" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Let my vindication come from your presence
tn.text: Here "presence" refers to Yahweh's being. AT: "Declare me innocent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: let your eyes see what is right!
tn.text: Here "your eyes" refers to that which Yahweh knows to be true. AT: "you know that I am telling the truth!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: If you test my heart, if you come to me in the night
tn.text: Here "test my heart" means to examine my thoughts and motives. AT: "If you examine my thoughts in the night" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: my mouth will not transgress
tn.text: Here the mouth is spoken of as if it were capable of acting on its own. It also represents the words that a person speaks. AT: "I will not tell lies or sin with my words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: it is at the word of your lips that I have kept myself from the ways of the lawless
tn.text: Here "the word of your lips" represents God's instruction. AT: "your instruction has caused me to avoid doing wicked things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: My steps have held firmly to your tracks; my feet have not slipped
tn.text: Both of these clauses mean the same thing. The repetition adds emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: my feet have not slipped
tn.text: The writer speaks of his obedience to God as if he were walking on a path. AT: "I am determined to follow your ways" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: turn your ear to me ... listen when I speak
tn.text: These phrases mean the same thing. Here "your ear" refers to God's willingness to hear someone who prays to him. AT: "pay attention to me ... listen when I speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: your right hand
tn.text: The "right hand" refers to God's power. AT: "your mighty power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: take refuge in you
tn.text: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. AT: "go to you for protection" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Protect me like the apple of your eye
tn.text: The "apple of your eye" refers to something that is valuable. AT: "Protect me as you would something most valuable and precious" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: hide me under the shadow of your wings
tn.text: David speaks of God's protection as if he were a bird protecting its young under its wings. AT: "Keep me safe as a mother bird protects her babies by gathering them under her wing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: their mouths speak with pride
tn.text: Here "their mouths speak" refers to what the people say. AT: "they are always boasting" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: They have surrounded my steps
tn.text: Here "surrounded my steps" represents how David's enemies have followed him everywhere he goes in order to capture him. AT: "My enemies have surrounded me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: like a lion eager for a victim, like a young lion crouching in hidden places
tn.text: These two phrases express very similar ideas. The repetition adds intensity. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: They are like a lion ... like a young lion
tn.text: The writer feels pursued the way a lion hunts its prey (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Rescue my life from the wicked by your sword ... Rescue me from men by your hand, Yahweh, from men of this world
tn.text: These two clauses have similar meanings. The repetition adds intensity to the writer's words. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: by your sword ... by your hand
tn.text: Here "sword" and "hand" both represent the power of Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: You will fill the bellies of your treasured ones with riches
tn.text: The ancient text is corrupt here. Possible meanings are 1) Yahweh will provide great blessings to his people. AT: "You will bless your people richly" or 2) Yahweh will greatly punish the wicked people to their children and grandchildren. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I will see your face in righteousness
tn.text: Here "face" represents Yahweh in all of his being. David is confident he will see Yahweh. AT: "because I act in the right way, I will be with you one day" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: I will be satisfied, when I awake, with a sight of you
tn.text: David believes that after he dies, he will be with Yahweh. This can be made clear in the translation. AT: "After I die, I will be happy to wake up in your presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
